top_articles.title: Two women allegedly assaulted on Catherine Connolly canvass in Dublin
top_articles.summary: Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald and Connolly supporters accosted by man in north inner city

raw_entry.title: Two women allegedly assaulted on Catherine Connolly canvass in Dublin

title_detail.value: Two women allegedly assaulted on Catherine Connolly canvass in Dublin

raw_entry.author: Conor Lally
raw_entry.summary: Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald and Connolly supporters accosted by man in north inner city

summary_detail.value: Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald and Connolly supporters accosted by man in north inner city

content.value: Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald casting her vote in the presidential election at the Deaf Village, Cabra west, Dublin, at lunchtime on Friday.  Photograph: Alan Betson

scraped_content.content:
Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald casting her vote in the presidential election at the Deaf Village, Cabra west, Dublin, at lunchtime on Friday. Photograph: Alan Betson

Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald and a group of supporters of presidential candidate Catherine Connolly were accosted, and two women allegedly assaulted, by a man in Dublin’s north inner city.

Gardaí have launched an investigation into the incident on Friday while Ms McDonald was leading a group of activists who were canvassing for Ms Connolly.

The man who approached the group recorded the aftermath of the alleged assault, with one woman seen sitting on a wall holding her face as she was surrounded by other activists.

Though the alleged assailant was encouraged by some of those present to walk away, he continued aggressively verbally abusing them and also made veiled threats to the group, including Ms McDonald, and shouted transphobic slurs.

He shouted expletives at those present, specifically targeting Ms McDonald at times, and threatened a man with physical violence when that person urged him to desist. The assailant took issue with some in the group wearing Palestinian badges, repeatedly shouting at them: “Where’s your Irish Tricolour, where’s the Tricolour?”

He also said to Ms McDonald: “I’m telling you, your time will come.” He then added: “I’m telling yous. Wait ‘til you f***ing see, every f***ing one of yous.”

A number of passersby, including those on foot and on bicycles, stopped at the scene, with the man heard shouting his camera was “slapped out of my hand and I gave her a slap in the face, so who’s right and who’s wrong”.

His video footage, now shared on social media, was being studied by gardaí in Store Street, Dublin 1, in a bid to identify the man and also gather evidence as part of the criminal investigation now under way.

The incident is the latest involving the targeting of politicians and their supporters while canvassing, especially in Dublin, with several others having been targeted during the general and local election campaigns last year.

In reply to queries, Garda Headquarters said members of the force “responded to a report of assault of two females on North Strand Road, Dublin 1, that occurred shortly before 4pm this afternoon”.

“No medical treatment was required at the scene, however An Garda Síochána understands that one of the females has since attended the Mater Misericordiae University Hospital for further assessment,” the reply added.

The Garda also appealed to anyone who witnessed the incident, or who had footage of the events, to come forward. The video recorded by the suspect has emerged publicly and was being studied closely as part of the investigation now under way.

Sinn Féin confirmed in a statement that gardaí were called and that an investigation had commenced. They confirmed a woman had been brought to hospital for medical examination.

“This happened as Mary Lou McDonald joined the canvass team, which is now continuing with its work of getting the vote out.”

It is understood Ms McDonald continued with the canvass, though others in the party were collected by the driver of a vehicle and taken away from the scene.
scraped_content.title: Two women allegedly assaulted on Catherine Connolly canvass in Dublin
scraped_content.authors: Conor Lally, Conor Lally Is Security, Crime Editor Of The Irish Times, Fri Oct -, Min Read

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in Irish politics have seen a significant statement from TD Mary Lou McDonald regarding the government's handling of housing crises, emphasizing the need for immediate action and increased funding for social housing. The government has announced new policies aimed at addressing these issues, but opposition parties are criticizing the measures as insufficient. Polling data indicates a shift in public sentiment, with rising support for Sinn Féin as citizens express dissatisfaction with current government policies. This situation highlights ongoing controversies surrounding housing and social welfare, impacting constituents across the nation.

top_articles.title: Victory for Connolly will raise many political questions
top_articles.summary: Catherine Connolly will be elected the country's tenth president this evening, writes Micheál Lehane.

raw_entry.title: Victory for Connolly will raise many political questions

title_detail.value: Victory for Connolly will raise many political questions

raw_entry.summary: Catherine Connolly will be elected the country's tenth president this evening, writes Micheál Lehane.

summary_detail.value: Catherine Connolly will be elected the country's tenth president this evening, writes Micheál Lehane.

scraped_content.content:
Catherine Connolly will be elected the country's tenth president this evening.

The vote will be a resounding one, but it will raise many political questions.

Firstly, will her strong views on things like neutrality and defence spending spark conflicts between the President and the Government?

On first reading that seems unlikely.

The Galway West TD has already spoken about the role of the presidency being different to the one she currently occupies.

One of her most striking comments during the campaign though was that she expected her regular discussions with the Taoiseach to be a two-way process.

That suggests that these meetings will not be mere courtesy calls, but robust conversations instead.

This is where any tensions could arise.

The Catherine Connolly victory will also give momentum to the Sinn Féin, Labour and Social Democrats' ambition to build a centre-left alternative in the lead-up to a general election.

It is evident too that the high number of spoiled votes will be a particularly notable feature of this election result.

This will lead to much debate and soul searching.

The political test is whether it leads to a change in the way future presidential candidates are selected.
scraped_content.title: Victory for Connolly will raise many political questions

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in the Irish government have seen Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe announce a new budget aimed at addressing the rising cost of living, which has sparked debates among TDs regarding its adequacy. Opposition leaders, including Mary Lou McDonald of Sinn Féin, have criticized the budget for not doing enough to support vulnerable citizens, while government officials defend it as a balanced approach. The budget's implications on social welfare and housing policy are expected to significantly impact constituencies across Ireland, with polling data indicating a shift in public opinion towards parties advocating for more substantial economic support.

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent debates in the Dáil have highlighted the government's proposed housing policy reforms, with TDs from various parties voicing strong opinions on the matter. Minister for Housing, Darragh O'Brien, defended the government's approach amidst criticism from opposition leaders, who argue that the measures are insufficient to address the ongoing housing crisis. Polling data indicates a shift in public sentiment towards housing issues, with many citizens expressing dissatisfaction with current government actions, potentially impacting upcoming elections.

top_articles.title: Man arrested over alleged assault on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald yesterday
top_articles.summary: A man in his 30s is detained at a garda station in the Dublin Metropolitan Region.

raw_entry.title: Man arrested over alleged assault on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald yesterday

title_detail.value: Man arrested over alleged assault on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald yesterday

raw_entry.summary: A man in his 30s is detained at a garda station in the Dublin Metropolitan Region.

summary_detail.value: A man in his 30s is detained at a garda station in the Dublin Metropolitan Region.

scraped_content.content:
A MAN IN his 30s has been arrested in relation to an alleged assault of two people while out on a canvas with Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald yesterday.

The incident happened on the North Strand Road, Dublin 1 at around 4pm.

A video circulating online shows canvassers standing between McDonald and a man who was verbally abusing her and other members of the group.

He also threatened to hit McDonald and others.

Advertisement

McDonald has been on a canvas in support of Catherine Connolly’s presidential bid.

A female was subsequently brought to hospital for medical examination.

A garda spokesperson yesterday said that while no medical treatment was required at the scene, An Garda Síochána understood that one of the females attended the Mater Misericordiae University Hospital for further assessment.

The man, aged in his 30s, is being detained at a Garda Station in the Dublin Metropolitan Region.
scraped_content.title: Man arrested over alleged assault on two people canvassing with Mary Lou McDonald yesterday
scraped_content.authors: Diarmuid Pepper, Send Tip Or Correction

The man, aged in his 30s, is being detained at a Garda Station in the Dublin Metropolitan Region.
top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in the Irish government have seen TDs from various parties responding to the latest budget proposals, with significant discussions around housing and healthcare funding. Minister for Finance has outlined a plan that aims to address the rising cost of living, which has sparked both support and criticism from opposition parties. Controversies have arisen regarding the allocation of resources, particularly in relation to rural versus urban needs, leading to heated debates in the Dáil. Polling data indicates a shift in public opinion regarding government performance, particularly in light of these budgetary decisions, which could impact upcoming elections.

top_articles.title: Graffiti on office is ‘attempt to intimidate me and my team’, Tipperary TD says
top_articles.summary: “Traitors” was written on the TD’s Thurles office where it was discovered this morning as voters went to the polls to elect the next president of Ireland.

raw_entry.title: Graffiti on office is ‘attempt to intimidate me and my team’, Tipperary TD says

title_detail.value: Graffiti on office is ‘attempt to intimidate me and my team’, Tipperary TD says

raw_entry.summary: “Traitors” was written on the TD’s Thurles office where it was discovered this morning as voters went to the polls to elect the next president of Ireland.

summary_detail.value: “Traitors” was written on the TD’s Thurles office where it was discovered this morning as voters went to the polls to elect the next president of Ireland.

scraped_content.content:
GARDAÍ ARE INVESTIGATING an incident of criminal damage at a TD’s constituency office in Co Tipperary.

Fianna Fail’s Ryan O’Meara, 30, who was elected as a TD for the first time in November, said graffiti on his office was an attempt to intimidate and disrupt him and his team.

The word “traitors” was written on the TD’s Thurles office where it was discovered on Friday morning as voters went to the polls to elect the next president of Ireland.

The TD for Tipperary North said “no one should face threats or intimidation at work”.

Democracy depends on public representatives being able to do their jobs without harassment or intimidation, and we cannot allow actions such as this to stand in the way of that.

“This morning’s attack on my office is more than an act of vandalism,” he said in a statement.

“It is a deliberate attempt to intimidate me and my team, and any action that threatens our democracy must not be tolerated.

“Those responsible are attempting to disrupt the work of my team. Any attack on politicians and their staff must be treated seriously, and I have contacted the gardaí.

Advertisement

“I want to acknowledge the members of my fantastic constituency team, who work every day to support our community.

“They do important work, providing advice and assistance to constituents, and it is completely unacceptable for anyone’s workplace to be targeted. No one should face threats or intimidation at work.

“These actions are a disservice to the community as a whole and an attack on the people of North Tipperary and North West Kilkenny, who democratically elected me as their local TD.

“Those responsible must be held to account. I will continue to ensure that my staff can work safely and without fear.

“Democracy depends on public representatives being able to do their jobs without harassment or intimidation, and we cannot allow actions such as this to stand in the way of that.”

Gardaí said they were investigating an incident of criminal damage to a building on Parnell Street in Thurles between Thursday night and Friday morning.

“Gardaí are appealing for witnesses – including those travelling in the area at the time who may have dashcam/video recordings,” it said.

“Anyone with any information is asked to contact Thurles Garda Station on 504 25100, the Garda Confidential Line on 1800 666 111, or any Garda Station.”
scraped_content.title: Graffiti on office is ‘attempt to intimidate me and my team’, Tipperary TD says
scraped_content.authors: Press Association, Send Tip Or Correction

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent discussions in the Dáil have centered around the government's proposed housing policy reforms aimed at addressing the ongoing housing crisis in Ireland. Several TDs, including Housing Minister Darragh O'Brien, have faced criticism from opposition parties regarding the effectiveness of these measures, with calls for more immediate action to support vulnerable citizens. The controversy has sparked a wider debate on the government's overall approach to social housing and its implications for upcoming elections, as polling data indicates a shift in public sentiment towards more progressive housing solutions.

top_articles.title: Gardaí called as Mary Lou McDonald and canvassers threatened on Dublin street
top_articles.summary: The incident happened at around 4pm on the city’s northside.

raw_entry.title: Gardaí called as Mary Lou McDonald and canvassers threatened on Dublin street

title_detail.value: Gardaí called as Mary Lou McDonald and canvassers threatened on Dublin street

raw_entry.summary: The incident happened at around 4pm on the city’s northside.

summary_detail.value: The incident happened at around 4pm on the city’s northside.

scraped_content.content:
SINN FÉIN LEADER Mary Lou McDonald was among canvassers threatened on a Dublin street today.

Gardaí are investigating the incident, which happened at around 4pm on North Strand Road, Dublin 1.

A video circulating online shows canvassers standing between McDonald and a man who was verbally abusing her and other members of the group. He also threatened to hit McDonald and others.

A woman was subsequently brought to hospital for medical examination.

The man can be heard saying: “Slap the phone out of my hand, you’ll get a slap in the face.”

He later says: “I’ll give her another bleeding slap.”

A child is also seen in the video.

A woman says, “watch my child,” and the man responds, “f*ck your child.”

The man can be heard shouting various names at individuals, such as “f*cking animal,” “bleeding tramp,” and “poisonous c*nt”.

Advertisement

He also used a transphobic slur multiple times.

He is heard threatening to “f*cking deck” one of the male canvassers.

A Sinn Féin spokesperson said that the incident happened as McDonald joined her local canvass team, which continued its work afterwards.

Polls opened this morning for the presidential election. McDonald and her party have backed Independent candidate Catherine Connolly.

Asked about the incident, a garda spokesperson said they responded to “a report of assault of two females on North Strand Road, Dublin 1″.

“No medical treatment was required at the scene, however An Garda Síochána understands that one of the females has since attended the Mater Misericordiae University Hospital for further assessment,” they said.

Gardaí are appealing to anyone with information or camera footage of the incident to contact Store Street Garda station on 01 666 8000.

Tánaiste and Fine Gael leader Simon Harris took to X to condemn the behaviour, which he said was appalling.

“Our democracy depends on people canvassing and advocating for their perspective and candidates,” he said.

“There is no place for abuse or threats. It’s vile and should be condemned outright by all.”

With reporting by Niall O’Connor and Jane Matthews.
scraped_content.title: Gardaí called as Mary Lou McDonald and canvassers threatened on Dublin street
scraped_content.authors: Mairead Maguire, Send Tip Or Correction

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent debates in the Dáil have highlighted significant divisions among TDs regarding the government's proposed housing policy reforms, with opposition parties criticizing the measures as inadequate. Minister for Housing Darragh O'Brien defended the government's approach, emphasizing the need for urgent action to address the housing crisis. Polling data indicates a shift in public sentiment, with growing support for alternative housing solutions proposed by smaller parties, raising questions about the government's long-term strategy and electoral viability. The ongoing controversy has sparked reactions from various constituencies, particularly those most affected by the housing shortage.

top_articles.title: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time
top_articles.summary: Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the final debate will kick off tonight on Prime Time

raw_entry.title: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time

title_detail.value: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time

raw_entry.summary: Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the final debate will kick off tonight on Prime Time

summary_detail.value: Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the final debate will kick off tonight on Prime Time

raw_entry.author: news@irishmirror.ie (Ciara O' Loughlin, Cathal Ryan)
raw_entry.media_keywords: Irish presidential election, In the News, RTE, Politics, Politics, Heather Humphreys, Catherine Connolly

scraped_content.content:
The final debate of the 2025 Irish Presidential Election will kick off on RTÉ’s Prime Time tonight.

Presented by Miriam O’Callaghan and Sarah McInerney, the live broadcast will feature candidates Catherine Connolly and Heather Humphreys.

Ahead of the debate Miriam O’Callaghan said, "I am so excited for this debate - it’s such a privilege to moderate these key Presidential election moments, to be involved and realise what a huge responsibility it is for our democracy. Every member of our Prime Time team has worked so hard to make sure this is a fair, thorough and enlightening debate."

From the Jim Gavin fiasco to the various heated debates, there's been no shortage of headline grabbing moments over the campaign - and there is still more to come before polling day this Friday.

Follow our live blog here for updates as they happen on tonight's debate. For more see our homepage.
scraped_content.title: LIVE: Final debate of 2025 Irish Presidential Election kicks off on Prime Time
scraped_content.authors: Ciara O' Loughlin, Cathal Ryan, Image, Conor O'Mearain Pa Wire

top_articles.ai_summary: Recent developments in Irish politics have seen TDs from various parties voicing their concerns over the government's proposed budget cuts, which are expected to impact social services significantly. Opposition leaders have criticized the government's approach, arguing that it disproportionately affects vulnerable communities, while the Finance Minister defended the measures as necessary for fiscal responsibility. Polling data indicates a shift in public sentiment, with rising support for alternative parties as citizens express dissatisfaction with current policies. The ongoing debate highlights the growing tensions within the Dáil and the potential implications for upcoming elections.

scraped_content.content:
Simon Harris: EU can play vital role in boosting humanitarian aid for Gaza

The Tánaiste will discuss a range of issues at a meeting of EU Foreign Ministers in Luxembourg today, including Russian aggression against Ukraine, the situation in the Middle East, and EU-Indo Pacific relations

View 2 Images Simon Harris (Image: Department of Foreign Affairs Ireland)

Tánaiste Simon Harris will say the EU can play a vital role in ramping up humanitarian aid for Gaza and express support for further sanctions on Russia at a meeting of EU Foreign Ministers today.

At the meeting in Luxembourg, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will discuss a range of issues with fellow foreign ministers, including Russian aggression against Ukraine, the situation in the Middle East, and EU-Indo Pacific relations.

Other items on the agenda include Moldova, Georgia, and Sudan.

Speaking ahead of the meeting, the Tánaiste said: “We gather at a critical moment for Ukraine and European security in the face of Russia’s continuing war of aggression. I look forward to hearing from the Ukrainian Foreign Minister Andrii Sybiha.

View 2 Images Tanaiste Simon Harris

“I condemn Russia’s ongoing missile attacks on Ukrainian cities and cynical attacks on critical infrastructure ahead of winter.

Article continues below

“I will be taking the opportunity to reiterate Ireland’s steadfast solidarity and support for Ukraine, our support for further sanctions on Russia, as well as our strong support for Ukraine’s EU accession.”

On the situation in the Middle East, the Tánaiste stated: “I welcome the recent announcement of a ceasefire and hostage release agreement. This is a significant achievement and the first step on a road to peace.

“We warmly welcome the release of 20 Israeli hostages after two long years in captivity. This is a moment of hope for them and their families. Every effort must also be made to find and release the bodies of deceased hostages.

“Our focus must now be on preserving the ceasefire and flooding Gaza with desperately needed humanitarian aid.

“I will be emphasising the important role that the EU can play in this regard. The people of Gaza have endured unimaginable suffering.

“Ireland has announced an additional €6 million in humanitarian aid for the people of Gaza to fund urgent food, medical care and other vital services.”

On Sudan, the Tánaiste said: “Ireland remains deeply concerned by the ongoing and devastating conflict in Sudan. We continue to call for a cessation of hostilities, followed by a permanent, peaceful and inclusive political settlement.

“We remain firmly committed to supporting the Sudanese people by providing vital humanitarian assistance and reiterate that urgent steps must be taken to ensure unhindered humanitarian access across the country.”

Article continues below

top_articles.ai_summary: In a recent parliamentary session, TDs debated the government's proposed housing policy, which aims to increase affordable housing availability amid rising rents. Opposition leaders criticized the plan, arguing it fails to address the root causes of the housing crisis, while government representatives defended it as a necessary step forward. The ongoing controversy has sparked significant public discourse, with recent polls indicating a decline in support for the ruling party as citizens express frustration over housing issues.
